reviewText:
You're here to figure out whether this game is worth playing.

I'm here to tell that it is. Here's the tl;dr: you don't have to believe me, you can try the base game (which contains a good 75% of the content for the main storyline) for free[steamcommunity.com], to your heart's content, while also enjoying any modifications available for it, which can be accessed through the community forums[forums.kronosaur.com], and all future updates. Yeah, for free -- no, not free2play, but free as in free to have fun.

What will you be buying?
So, Transcendence has a long term development plan. New versions are going to be released with no end in sight, as far as I know. Transcendence, the base engine, allows you to play adventures in the Transcendence universe. This base engine is free.

The primary adventure (yes, there are others, well explained by this infographic)[transcendence.kronosaur.com] is that of a character who hears the voice of a hyper-intelligence calling them to the centre of the universe, and listens to the voices in their head -- this adventure is called Domina and Oracus"
recommended: Part 1 of the story has been released
hoursPlayed: along with a content expansion pack called Corporate Command
voteText: but the expansion pack is not free.\n\nThere is another official adventure that has been released
helpfulPercent: and this one is called "Eternity Port". It is about a character who is left for dead in the depths of space after an attack on their ship
votesHelpful: only to be saved by a selfish (I saved you
votesTotal: so *obviously* you owe me) entity representing the virtual citizens of Eternity Port. They want you to do something for them
votesFunny: starting off the adventure. This adventure isn't free. If you want to see how Eternity Port fits into the lore of the Transcendence universe
commentsCount: check out the infographic[transcendence.kronosaur.com] I mentioned earlier.\n\nYou're buying Corporate Command (the expansion content for the main adventure)
column16: together with Eternity Port (the other official adventure); in other words
column17: you're buying all the content that exists so far
column18: and costs money.\n\nHow are basic things like the graphics
column19: UI and sound design?\nThe graphics are pretty
column20: as you can see from screen shots. Starry space backgrounds
column21: mixed with the foreground composed of ships
column22: planets and stations with textures that fit in perfectly. Even though this is an independently developed game
column23: it doesn't skimp out on graphics by pretending to be "retro"
column24: or trying to get into the good books of old-schoolers with trashy UI design. The game's graphics are modern
column25: and suit the gameplay.\n\nThe game has a soundtrack that's original and beautiful (I am humming the music that starts you off on an adventure right now)
column26: and has sound effects that aren't archaic. While allowing for some mouse interaction in menus
column27: the UI is mostly designed to take keyboard input
column28: but isn't painful to use because of that decision
column29: and most gamers will feel at home right away: the arrow keys move your ships around in interesting ways
column30: and major buttons like the spacebar or control keys handle the firing of weapons. Keyboard shortcuts usually make sense etymologically (e.g. "D" for Dock
column32: and there is an excellent help infographic that is accessible any time in the game that lists out all the keyboard shortcuts.\n\nSo
column33: space adventure game. What will I actually be doing?\nThe storylines
column34: depending on which adventure you are playing
column35: give some background as to why you are setting off in space
column36: and then some occasional guiding structure throughout. What do you do in between? Well
column37: it's up to you.\n\nYou can trade: there are minerals to be mined
column38: the ore sold or forged into useful armour
column39: which can be sold for an even higher price. Or
column40: you can go about simply buying low and selling high
column41: making a living for yourself that allows you to buy fuel and the ammunition needed to stay safe. Maybe you decide you're interested in also running a side business in the black market. Well
column42: as long as you have a murky sense of morality
column44: and the know how to hide your goods from the authorities
column45: maybe you'll be successful.\n\nYou can sign up with the Commonwealth Forces
column46: or some of the other regional powers (depending on which adventure you are playing)
column47: and rise up through the ranks. You can meditate in the halls of the Sisters of Domina's temples. Maybe you can figure out what this voice in your head wants. Maybe you are interested in donating items to the Sisters' cause
column48: and helping the needy that you meet in beaten down habitat stations that are nothing more than cargo containers strung together.\n\nMaybe you free slaves held in living stasis inside coffins by the Sung Slavers
column49: as you attempt to make sure you aren't squashed by them. Maybe you get involved in story of the Sung and the Huari
column50: the Aztec/Maya-esque space culture that was decimated by the Sung's relentless ruthlessness. Maybe some zoanthrope buddies tag along because you beat their masters
column51: and thus are next most powerful thing they know to follow. Maybe you willingly submit yourself to the nasty experiments of humans who have genetically modified themselves to such a degree that they might as well be aliens.\n\nMaybe you actually bump into aliens
column52: and other creepy-crawlies. Maybe. It's your call. The game is detailed enough to waste hours of your time
column53: with nice flavour text to spice up every piece of the universe. Bring your imagination along
column54:
and go for a ride.

What about mods?
Transcendence is heavily modifiable
column55: and has an active community of modders: everything in the universe can be described and programmed with XML files and a custom LISP variant (TransLisp). The C++ guts of Transcendence are completely open as well
column56: and available for viewing and participation on GitHub. Modding documentation is sparse
column57: but community participation makes up for it.\n\nSo
column59: Transcendence will give you lots to do. If you like playing with other people's modifications
column60: Transcendence won't disappoint you there either. Popular mods include a complete revamp of the mining system
column61: AI based modifications that allow the game world to be even more dynamic by randomly generating conflict and rebuilding stations
column62: content packs that add new weapons or features such as the ability to craft new weapons from components
column63: and so on.\n\nI can't help but quote something really relevant from one of the prominent modders
column65: on why he loves the game:\n\nOriginally posted by pixelfck: The storyline is quite deep
column66: with promise for even more; There is a lot of content (devices
column69: many of which hook back into the background universe; Its open source (Â© George Moromisato); I can mod it (step 1: initial notion); The modding system has a quite powerful scripting available (step 2: the promise); All vanilla content has been made with the modding options available to me
column70: no hard-coded 'magic' (step 3: the realisation of full potential);\nFinal words.\nMy recommendation is that you try out the free content. Get yourself into the community and modifications
column71: if that interests you. If you love it all
column73: buy the Steam version that contains all content
column74: or buy the content piecemeal as you want to using Kronosaur's "Multiverse" infrastructure. Like pixelfck
column76: and think about how you can contribute too
column77: because I want to play your mod!"

reviewText: This game will hook you. Very fun to run around and fight, collect, upgrade and...die. You can restart from your last save position though. Enough to do so it doesn't get boring after the first hours or systems. I played this for a bit off the dev's web site (some have been playing for years, so yes it is supported). One initial problem with the Steam release was addressed quickly and professionally with good communication.\n\nThink single player ELITE from an overhead prospective.
voteText: 26 of 26 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: I have been playing Transcendence on and off for about ten years, and I count it among my favorite games.  I keep coming back to this game because with each new version there is always something new to explore and it can easily be modded.  The long development process has led to a game that has a depth rarely seen in indie games.  If you are unsure about purchasing this try out the free version from http://kronosaur.com.  It is a full game not just a demo, the steam version just includes the expansion packs.

reviewText: Great little game, it's like a bullet hell game, space sim, rpg and rougelike all in one. Since it was my first time playing it took a little bit to get used to the hotkeys and controls, but you can change it in the .ini and there will soon be a in-game UI for it.\n\nI wish I found out about it earlier, hearing from others that it has been around for awhile now. Fun times~ Can't wait to see all the mods.

reviewText: A top-down space shooter/roguelike with randomised star systems, a heck of a lot of content, and many, many ways to die. In active development since 2003 or so, this game has a lot of history.\nI've been playing since 2008 and I still find new tricks. Highly moddable with an active community. Recommended.

reviewText: Listen. This is an OG overhead space sim. Crafted in the days of Tyrian and Escape Velocity, back when floppy and ZIP disks were a thing and you burned Awesome Summer Mix" onto a CD

reviewText: An excellent game! I've played this since the 0.95 version came out, and it's been great ever since. The base game is actually free and will take about 1-2 weeks to complete. The Corporate Command and Eternity Port expansions add lots more ships, systems, enemies, missions and plot-lines to follow, and are well worth the 8 bucks. This is like Escape Velocity, but better. And a lot more difficult. One caveat though - you can't switch ships, so you're stuck with whatever you picked at the beginning. There's a mod called Playership Drones" I remember installing some time ago
date: it allowed you to buy new ships and even use them as wingmen.\n\nThis is really an open-world sandbox
recommended: where you can make your own decisions and do whatever you feel like doing. You can escort freighters
voteText: work for the military
votesTotal: even become a gladiator. Be warned though
votesFunny: your actions and choices will always have consequences both good and bad. Gameplay can be very challenging at times
commentsCount: especially the combat which requires good reflexes. Pick the Wolfen gunship and you'll see what I mean. There can be quite a steep learning  curve  cliff
column16: and you'll get blown up. A lot. You can resurrect and pick up from where you left off
column17: with no penalties apart from a lowered high score. On my first play-through I died about 25 times.\n\nSome tips: Learn the trade routes
column18: and how to profit from the black market. Don't hesitate to use exploits like sitting on a planet (they're invulnerable) while waiting for your shields to recharge
column19: or luring enemies to a friendly station to be killed. When about to die
column20: press (I>1). You can attack salvager nomads (big brown ships) and smugglers (gray transports with small escorts) with no penalties. They are easy to defeat and carry good loot. Don't attack the Huari. And definitely don't feed the Teraton fabricator radioactive waste :) Also
column21: remember to have fun and don't get discouraged by the amount of times you get blown up. It's very rewarding when you complete the game at last. Just resurrect and try again. And again.\n\n10/10 would die again."

reviewText: Awesome this game is finally on Steam!  I have played this on and off for years (since version 0.8 more than ten years ago) and the game keeps improving with each update.  This is a strong recommend if you are in the mood for a rougelike top-down space game like Escape Velocity Nova or Star Control 2 (sans planetary landings), with plenty of replayability given the random nature each game.\n\nLooking forward to seeing Part II.

reviewText:
Been playing this game on again and off again for about 8 years now. It might not look like much but it's strangely addictive and it's fascinating to watch it evolve. Highlights
-Fantastic mod system. Easy to get into and understand. It's easy to understand the game data script and understand it even without any coding experience
-Very complex mechanics. It seems simple enough on the surface but there is a lot to discover, and a variety of play styles to try.
-Constantly in development. I've seen the game change from 8 years ago and I know development had been going on for a more than that. It slows and speeds up but it never stops. It's a one man developed game, but the dev is responsive and actively talks to the community.
-Content. LOTS, I mean it. LOTS.
-Graphics and audio. Well, it's not cutting edge, but then even a netbook will happily run it. Play anywhere game. You can save randomly and come back as you please
voteText: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Awesome space shooter! The flying controlls might take a bit to get used to, but it feels great. I like the amount of weapons, armor and tech you can install on your ship to define your own way to play the game.
One big complaint I have is that the enemy AI is literally potatoes. You can shoot an enemy base from outside the invividual ships aggro range and as long as you don't hit them they don't give a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, only when the enemy base explodes they start chasing you. Even then it is really easy to just get a nice speed up, turn around and shoot at them outside of their range until they die. Or aggro them to an allied space station where they get wrecked, since they don't have a base to return to, the enemies keep chasing after you until you or they die.

Over all I really enjoy this game though, even with the ridiculously broken enemy AI it's fun to shoot and kite them around.

reviewText:
Holy crud this game is cool. Remember Escape Velocity? This is one of the closest things I've found to EV. Its an entirely keyboard driven (in a good way) top-down space game. Travel around, join factions, do missions, trade, fight etc. Its really fun.

Its easy enough to pick up and play, although deep enough that you can spend hours travelling around and customizing your ship. I havent found out if you can buy a new ship or if you have the same ship the entire game so make sure you pick what you want fropm the start. Theres a type of ship for every gameplay style. I prefer the Manticore Heavy Fighter. Its got enough gun slots to do serious damage, but also has a decent cargo space to carry stuff. Its a tank though, so make sure you get nice arnor, youre not going to be zipping around in it.

Theres a ton of different ships, armor, weapons, items. Graphics are what youd expect, little ships of all shapes and sizes flying around with a tiny comet of flame" coming out of the rear end when you fire thrusters. Lasers are lines
date: and shots are little round blips. Typical top down space game graphics
recommended: but they arent bad. The music is awesome
hoursPlayed: lots of Empire Strikes Back style scores.\n\nDo not
voteText: under any circustances run out of fuel. You use fuel to power everything. If you run out
helpfulPercent: game over. Literally. No floating randomly about or hailing a passing ship. (AFAIK there is no communication between ships
votesHelpful: or maybe I just dont have the ship piece yet to do that).\n\nThe game does let you ressurrect by loading a save after death
votesTotal: although there is a notation for "respecting permadeath" on your charsheet
votesFunny: so it knows if you do this. Best of both worlds
commentsCount: IMHO.\n\nThe story's interesting and weird. I was doing a bunch of random sidequests
column16: of the go blow up (x) or escort (y) vein. I was told to go blow up an anarchist space station. I did and docked to loot (always fun - docking to loot stations and ships I just blew up!)
column17: when suddenly.... a story plot happened on the station. It was an interesting story hook too. So there is more to the story than just the main plot.\n\nIf you like EV
column18: you'll like this game. I just wish you could hail/threaten/communicate with other passing ships
column19: and there was more faction subplots
column20: but thats a relatively minor gripe. Its a good game."

reviewText:
What is transcendence about?

transcendence is a rouguelike topdown space action RPG. you take the role of a space ship wich mission is to reach the galactic core. you will travel from solar system to solarsystem in search for better weapons, better armor and varios sidequest. and then reapeat the process until you die.

is the game worth playing?

this is a tough question. it depends on your personal preferences. however I will say that I enjoyed the game a great deal but this game is certainly not perfect. the biggest complaint I have is that this game does a very bad job in explaining how evrything works. it explains how to control your ship but that is all. This game is extremly dificult and it requires some time investment before you get the hang of it.

this is a rogue like game so you need to expect dying several times and start all over again, some people like that and others do not. but unlike many modern roguelike games transcendence lack an unlock system. wich means that dying can sometimes feel like a waste of times since you dont get a reward for playing.

the controls are abit awkard to use. you only navigate your ship with the keyboard. you use the W" key to accelerate forward and "A" and "D" to turn your ship. since you dont use the mouse you canot excecute precise movements.

This game is however full of content. there are huge amounts of different weapons and armor you can find and each round feel very diferent.

in short if you like rouguelike games wich are set in space. and dont mind awkard contros this game might be for you"
voteText: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Full Video Review and Gameplay: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-pHVFf7Kj3I

Transcendence is an addictive open-world space exploration game with a ton of replay value.  If you enjoyed FTL you'll like this game.

I'm a huge fan of permanent death.  It made getting fuel or escaping a tricky situation so much more rewarding.

Pros
- Addicting
- Tons of Replay Value
- Multiple ships to choose from
- Random quest and encounters
- Heavy story elements (that can be skipped)

Cons
- Controls can be tricky at first
- The progression is fairly linear
- Ecounters can feel repetitive at times

Overall, if the game looks interesting to you I would definitely recommend it.  It's a nice little casual game to kill some time.
voteText: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I bought this game before it was released on Steam so my gameplay hours are not the actual ones.\n\nGood 2D space sim, similar to Escape Velocity Nova, but this is more of a roguelike as your goal is to progress deeper and deeper into the galaxy via jump gates to more and more difficult systems.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I'm a community admin, but I only got to the positions I have in the community through my love for and dedication to this game for the last... 8? years. So thats got to speak volumes alone for this game, at least from me.

Yes I would wholeheartedly recommend this game, especially to people who like to make game mods.
This is one of the... actually the only game that has kept me around in its community for nearly an entire decade. The base game on its own is fun and replayable due to the procedural nature of it, though the massive collection of user-made content for this (most of it can be found here: http://xelerus.de/  - also check out the modding boards on the forums here: https://forums.kronosaur.com/viewforum.php?f=11 )

Getting into modding the game isn't hard at all, theres plenty of tutorials to get you started.

This game has been in active development for the past 13 years with fixes, content, expansions still coming out (even moreso than before)

PLUS: you can try the game out for free! Its a very small download, what are you waiting for?
(Also supports Windows 10, and runs under WINE on linux or OSX)
http://transcendence.kronosaur.com/
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is a real fun game with good gameplay and an interesting plot. The replay value is great as the system maps are generated randomly. This is one of the fact why I am playing this game again despite having completed it back in 2010. The first half (I think) is free and you can find it over at kronosaur.com if you are unsure about buying this game. Give that a go and, if you like it, come back and buy this to support the developer. All in all, a solid 8.5/10.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I've been playing this on and off for like ten years, and it's the best. It's basically pure gameplay, very much like Escape Velocity etc. It's an old-school top down space shooter, with a roguelike twist -- gates for stairs, mysterious barrels and ROMs replace potions and scrolls. It's simple enough on the surface to be picked up basically instantly, but with a lot of depth in the customization of your ship, and the way you fight. If you've played the original story, I recommend this anyways just to do the expansion. It's not just more of the same -- it's quite expanded compared to the original campaign, including new factions, mechanics (non-linear  star map!), etc.\n\nHighly recommended!

reviewText:
TL:DR:
No sound settings. No control settings. No Mouse control. Annoying music. Do not buy, even on sale (I did, I wish I didn't).

Graphics is nice, but the game is missing basic options, which is unforgivable these days.
Gameplay is kinda 'meh', sound is annoying and cannot be turned off, storyline is boring.
Controlling your craft is kinda like in old asteroids game, but more clunky.

I don't know why this game has so many positive reviews, it does some things right, but that is not enough to recommend it to anyone.
If you are looking for:
- in depth, captivating story
- stunning visual effects
- atmospheric and memorable music
- intense combat action
- trading and economic sandbox experience

You are not going to find it here. This game actually plays *worse* than Space Rangers, and offers like 1/10 of fun related to SR.

reviewText:
I started playing Transcendence 4-5 years ago.
Personally I like the early game the best for its abundance of gameplay such as fighting in the arena, escorting freighters, and the need to run away often. For me, the greatest part of the game is its universe with just enough details to let your mind fill in the rest.

Of course I can't make a review of Transcendence without talking about its support of mods. No third party mod installer is needed. You can just download or make the xml files you want and drop it into the Extensions" folder (make one if needed) in the same location as the Transcendence.exe game file. Also its modding language is extremely user friendly."
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Finally! Finally! After years of lurking on the forums, my favorite game is on steam!
Anyone questioning whether to buy this masterpiece listen up: Trancendence puts Escape Velocity to shame!
-A Beatiful, intricate universe with a very open ended story.
-Gladiator fighting
-Drug smuggling
-Piracy!
-Mining, crafting, trading...
-Doing none of those things and blowing up Space-Ant (Ferian) Colonies instead!
-Or all of the above!
Seriously, I've played this for years before it came out on steam and lived doubles lives as fleet commander and drug lord, as well as defended and betrayed the human race over many, MANY playthroughs. Best replay value of any rougelike out there.
